summary: Email correspondence between attorneys and a U.S. Attorney's Office representative regarding a draft protective order for the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The discussion focuses on language revisions to ensure limited dissemination of the agreement to victims and their acknowledgment of the order's terms.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Represents petitioners (victims) in the Epstein case; proposes revisions to the protective order language to facilitate quicker access to the non-prosecution agreement and focuses on client acknowledgment.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Co-counsel for petitioners; involved in discussions about the protective order and the urgency of accessing the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the non-prosecution agreement; referenced as allegedly trying to ignore the agreement, prompting urgency in the legal proceedings.

connections.description: Co-counsel representing petitioners (victims) in the Epstein case, collaborating on protective order negotiations.
Cassell represents victims against Epstein; the protective order concerns disclosure of Epstein's non-prosecution agreement.
Edwards represents victims against Epstein; involved in efforts to access the non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Government representations about Epstein ignoring agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office represented that Jeffrey Epstein is trying to ignore the non-prosecution agreement, creating urgency for victims' attorneys to access the document.

events.title: Draft protective order negotiations
events.description: Email exchange finalizing language for a protective order governing disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement to victims, with revisions proposed by Paul Cassell.

locations: University of Utah S. J. Quinney College of Law
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office disclosed that Jeffrey Epstein was allegedly trying to ignore the non-prosecution agreement, prompting urgency among victims' attorneys.
A protective order was being negotiated to limit dissemination of the non-prosecution agreement, requiring victims to acknowledge and abide by its terms before disclosure.
Paul Cassell proposed revisions to the protective order to expedite access by focusing on client acknowledgment rather than prior written approval from the U.S. Attorney's Office.
The correspondence highlights tensions between victims' attorneys and the government over the scope of the protective order, with the government viewing the petitioners' proposal as overly broad.
